fuz.merge 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Fuzzy_Match

    Fuzzy_Match

    Kenneth Stevenson and Harrison Karp

    2019-12-11

    intro.Rmd

    Often when we want to join two tables together, we don’t have unique ID to join by and have to use a column they have in common, often names. A lot of the time the data is entered manually so there might be typos in the names, or it might use a different format. For example, one might include prefixes or suffixes while the other might not. To do a normal join these columns would not match. The fuz.merge package allows us to join tables based on approximate matches and provides other functions to facilitate this process to ensure matches are accurate.

    The Function

    The primary function of this package is fuzzy_match

      fuzzy_match(table1, table2, by1, by2, method = "jw", cutoff = .1, join_type = "inner", sort = "desc")

    The function implements fuzzy matching by calculating finding the closest match between tables where the distance between the two values is less than the specified cutoff.

    Data Sets

    • The congress data frame has information on 541 U.S. Congressmembers and was retrieved from data.world

    • The politwoops data frame has 1852 observations of various public officials who are being tracked by Politwoops for deleting tweets and was retrieved from propublica.org

    Example: Inner Join

    library(fuz.merge)
congress <- dplyr::select(congress, name, gender)
politwoops <- dplyr::select(politwoops, full_name, user_name, account_type)
congress$name <- scramble(congress$name, 2)
politwoops$full_name <- scramble(politwoops$full_name, 1)

congress[1:10,"name"]
#>  [1] "Sherrod Bgomn"    "Maria Cantwyll"   "Beu Cardbn"       "Tom Carper"      
#>  [5] "Bob Casey, Jr."   "Boz porker"       "DiagnesFeinstein" "Orrio Hytch"     
#>  [9] "Amy Klobubhar"    "Claire McCaskill"
politwoops[1:10,"full_name"]
#> # A tibble: 10 x 1
#>    full_name     
#>    <chr>         
#>  1 Matt Connolly 
#>  2 Lisa Scheller 
#>  3 Susan Collins 
#>  4 Woodx Thrasher
#>  5 Tom Tiffanz   
#>  6 Michael Opela 
#>  7 Amanda Stuck  
#>  8 Tricia Zunker 
#>  9 Jason Church  
#> 10 Jessica qing

    The scramble function randomly changed characters for the names so we can test the fuzzy_match. First we want to use the clean() function on each dataset so we can minimize the differences between the two columns we are going to join by.

    congress <- clean(congress, name, selected = ",", suffixes = T, prefixes = T)
congress[1:20,1]
#>  [1] "Sherrod Bgomn"         "Maria Cantwyll"        "Beu Cardbn"           
#>  [4] "Tom Carper"            "Bob Casey"             "Boz porker"           
#>  [7] "DiagnesFeinstein"      "Orrio Hytch"           "Amy Klobubhar"        
#> [10] "Claire McCaskill"      "nob Msnendez"          "Bill Nelson wFmorida)"
#> [13] "Bernie Sanders"        "Debbie Stabenow"       "Jzn Tesper"           
#> [16] "Shesden Whitehouse"    "Johnnbarrasso"         "Roder Wicker"         
#> [19] "wamar Alexacder"       "Thad Cochran"

    So now we have removed the prefixes, suffixes and commas from each column of names.

    df <- fuzzy_match(congress, politwoops, name, full_name, cutoff = .1, 
                  join_type = "inner", sort = "desc")
df[1:15,]
#>                  name gender       full_name         match_vals       user_name
#> 1      Lisa Murkowski      F  Lisa Murkiwski 0.0989010989010989   lisamurkowski
#> 2  Robert B. Aderholt      M Roqert Aderholt 0.0962962962962963 Robert_Aderholt
#> 3      Chucq Grasslgy      M  Chuck Grassley 0.0952380952380952   ChuckGrassley
#> 4      Ranvy Hultgoen      M  Randy Hultgren 0.0952380952380952     RepHultgren
#> 5      Richqrd Shhlby      M  Richard Shelby 0.0952380952380952       SenShelby
#> 6      Joaquin Casyjo      M  Joaquin Castro 0.0952380952380952 Castro4Congress
#> 7      MarthaoMcSaoly      F  Martha McSally 0.0952380952380952    SenMcSallyAZ
#> 8      Debvie Dhngell      F  Debbie Dingell 0.0952380952380952   RepDebDingell
#> 9      Debvie Dhngell      F  Debbie Dihgell 0.0952380952380952      debdingell
#> 10     haise Stefanik      F  Ekise Stefanik 0.0952380952380952     RepStefanik
#> 11     haise Stefanik      F  Ekise Stefanik 0.0952380952380952   EliseStefanik
#> 12     haise Stefanik      F  Ekise Stefanik 0.0952380952380952     RepStefanik
#> 13     haise Stefanik      F  Ekise Stefanik 0.0952380952380952   EliseStefanik
#> 14     Mikg Gallaghed      M  Mike Gallagher 0.0952380952380952    RepGallagher
#> 15     Mikg Gallaghed      M  Mike Gallagher 0.0952380952380952       MikeforWI
#>    account_type
#> 1      official
#> 2      official
#> 3      official
#> 4      official
#> 5      official
#> 6      campaign
#> 7      official
#> 8      official
#> 9      campaign
#> 10     official
#> 11     campaign
#> 12     official
#> 13     campaign
#> 14     official
#> 15     campaign

    Using the sort argument sorted the table in descending order of the match_vals column so the row at top is the least accurate. Looking at the by.x and by.y column, it’s clear that this is the correct merge. The probability of having a mismatch further down is low since the first row had the biggest string distance between the matching columns.
